articles.headline: Employing Dietitians Pays Off for Supermarkets
articles.snippet: As nutrition is becoming more important to customers, the grocery business is finding dietitians indispensable for fending off competition from specialty markets.
articles.abstract: As nutrition is becoming more important to customers, the grocery business is finding dietitians indispensable for fending off competition from specialty markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOLINE, Ill. — Lois E. Florence recently left her doctor’s office with a diagnosis of colitis, an intestinal disorder, and a complicated set of instructions for changing her diet.

articles.headline: How to Know if You Have Enough Auto Insurance
articles.snippet: Auto accidents that cause major injuries are rare, but it still may be worth examining how much insurance coverage you have.
articles.abstract: Auto accidents that cause major injuries are rare, but it still may be worth examining how much insurance coverage you have.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like a good scare to send us all scurrying to our auto insurance policy to see what our coverage is. This month, those of us who have followed the story of Progressive Insurance and the Fisher family got one.

articles.headline: In Euro Crisis, Fingers Can Point in All Directions
articles.snippet: While it is true that a series of Greek governments bears a large share of the guilt for the euro crisis, for mismanaging their economy and finances, there are plenty of other culprits.
articles.abstract: While it is true that a series of Greek governments bears a large share of the guilt for the euro crisis, for mismanaging their economy and finances, there are plenty of other culprits.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The debate about how to distribute the cost of preserving the euro often centers on a fundamental question that is unspoken but implicit: Who caused this crisis anyway?

articles.headline: Jury Awards $1 Billion to Apple in Samsung Patent Case
articles.snippet: The jury found that Samsung infringed upon a series of Apple patents on mobile devices, in a closely watched court case that could have broad implications for the industry.
articles.abstract: The jury found that Samsung infringed upon a series of Apple patents on mobile devices, in a closely watched court case that could have broad implications for the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple won a decisive victory on Friday in a lawsuit against Samsung, a verdict that will give Apple ammunition in a far-flung patent war with its global competitors in the smartphone business.

articles.headline: Cash Moves by HSBC in Inquiry
articles.snippet: Federal authorities said the bank was suspected of laundering money for Mexican drug cartels and moving cash for Saudi Arabian banks with ties to terrorists.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities said the bank was suspected of laundering money for Mexican drug cartels and moving cash for Saudi Arabian banks with ties to terrorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors investigating the movement of money by global banks suspect HSBC of laundering money for Mexican drug cartels and moving cash for Saudi Arabian banks with ties to terrorists, according to federal authorities with direct knowledge of the investigations.

articles.headline: Romney in Crisis: Two Dark Spots in Fortunate Life
articles.snippet: A 1968 car crash in France and the 1998 diagnosis of Ann Romney’s multiple sclerosis offer clues into Mitt Romney’s character, and how he reacts to challenges.
articles.abstract: A 1968 car crash in France and the 1998 diagnosis of Ann Romney’s multiple sclerosis offer clues into Mitt Romney’s character, and how he reacts to challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney was, uncharacteristically, terrified.

articles.headline: A Verdict That Alters an Industry
articles.snippet: Companies that make smartphones will have to be cautious in how they design products to avoid being accused of imitating Apple.
articles.abstract: Companies that make smartphones will have to be cautious in how they design products to avoid being accused of imitating Apple.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal court jury’s decision Friday in a smartphone patent lawsuit between Apple and Samsung is expected to alter the dynamics of the highly competitive mobile phone industry.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Lisa Alcalay Klug

articles.headline: The Best Book Reviews Money Can Buy
articles.snippet: The growing business of self-published books has spawned an industry in which hired reviewers produce favorable online reviews.
articles.abstract: The growing business of self-published books has spawned an industry in which hired reviewers produce favorable online reviews.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULSA , Okla.

articles.headline: When a 401(k) Is Locked in the Freezer
articles.snippet: After their company’s bankruptcy, a group of workers has waited four years for their retirement money.
articles.abstract: After their company’s bankruptcy, a group of workers has waited four years for their retirement money.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERYONE with a 401(k) knows that bad investments and high fees can threaten their retirement. But what if the company that sponsors your plan goes bankrupt?

articles.headline: For Big Givers, Cash and Clout Arrive Together
articles.snippet: Lobbyists, corporate executives, trade associations and donors exploit legal loopholes, making each party’s quadrennial convention a gathering of money and influence unrivaled in politics.
articles.abstract: Lobbyists, corporate executives, trade associations and donors exploit legal loopholes, making each party’s quadrennial convention a gathering of money and influence unrivaled in politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: The railway giant CSX, which has spent $2 million this year lobbying on issues like greenhouse-gas regulation and hazardous-waste transportation rules, will park special train cars near the Tampa Bay Times Forum to host parties and meetings.

articles.headline: Young and Alone, Facing Court and Deportation
articles.snippet: An unexpected surge of children, some of them barely school age, have been caught by border agents as they tried to cross illegally into the United States.
articles.abstract: An unexpected surge of children, some of them barely school age, have been caught by border agents as they tried to cross illegally into the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARLINGEN, Tex. — The judge called his next case, scanning the courtroom.

articles.headline: Romney Adopts Harder Message for Last Stretch
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney is heading into his nominating convention with his advisers convinced he needs a more combative footing against President Obama.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney is heading into his nominating convention with his advisers convinced he needs a more combative footing against President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney is heading into his nominating convention with his advisers convinced he needs a more combative footing against President Obama in order to appeal to white, working-class voters and to persuade them that he is the best answer to their economic frustrations.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Crackdown Toll Seen as Syrians Bury Hundreds
articles.snippet: With more than 200 bodies found over the weekend, the assault in Daraya, a suburb of Damascus has begun to look like one of the deadliest short-term raids of the uprising.
articles.abstract: With more than 200 bodies found over the weekend, the assault in Daraya, a suburb of Damascus has begun to look like one of the deadliest short-term raids of the uprising.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARAYA, Syria — Mass burials in this Damascus suburb on Sunday showed the carnage of the past few days in gruesome detail: scores of bodies lined up on top of one another in long, thin graves moist with mud.
articles.byline: By An Employee of The New York Times in Syria and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Disruptions: At Box, a Fast-Moving Chief Immersed in the Cloud
articles.snippet: Aaron Levie founded the online data storage company Box from his dorm room seven years ago and turned it into one of the fastest-growing companies in Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: Aaron Levie founded the online data storage company Box from his dorm room seven years ago and turned it into one of the fastest-growing companies in Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ALTOS, Calif. — It’s about 20 minutes into my lunch interview with Aaron Levie, co-founder of Box, at the headquarters of the online data storage company, and he still doesn’t have any food.

articles.headline: Inventor Challenges a Sweeping Revision in Patent Law
articles.snippet: Mark Stadnyk is suing the United States government, aiming to block a patent law that he says is a triumph of corporate lobbying that will hurt lone inventors like him.
articles.abstract: Mark Stadnyk is suing the United States government, aiming to block a patent law that he says is a triumph of corporate lobbying that will hurt lone inventors like him.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Silicon Valley, Apple just won big against Samsung in the patent lawsuit of the year, after trading claims and counterclaims of pilfered product ideas. Across the country, in a federal court in Florida, an inventor named Mark Stadnyk is waging a different kind of patent warfare — an ambitious and perhaps quixotic legal foray.

articles.headline: Viewers Don’t Want Conventional
articles.snippet: If political convention organizers acknowledged that they were putting on reality shows, television networks and viewers might be more inclined to watch.
articles.abstract: If political convention organizers acknowledged that they were putting on reality shows, television networks and viewers might be more inclined to watch.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the political conventions were managed like a typical television show that was losing audience, think of the meetings that would be held during the run-up.

articles.headline: Jimmy Kimmel’s Move May Seal Fate of ‘Nightline’
articles.snippet: The decision to shift “Jimmy Kimmel Live” into the time slot long held by “Nightline” is a hurtful and possibly fatal blow to the program, former members of the news show say.
articles.abstract: The decision to shift “Jimmy Kimmel Live” into the time slot long held by “Nightline” is a hurtful and possibly fatal blow to the program, former members of the news show say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jimmy Kimmel’s ascent to the main stage of late-night television — the hour directly after the 11 p.m. local news — was greeted last week with widespread congratulations for a performer who had paid his dues and for a network willing to shake up the late-night status quo and bet on a comedic challenger to David Letterman and Jay Leno.

articles.headline: Egyptian Leader Adds Rivals of West to Syria Plan
articles.snippet: Staking out a new leadership role for Egypt, President Mohamed Morsi is reaching out to Iran and other regional powers in an initiative to halt the violence in Syria.
articles.abstract: Staking out a new leadership role for Egypt, President Mohamed Morsi is reaching out to Iran and other regional powers in an initiative to halt the violence in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Staking out a new leadership role for Egypt in the shaken landscape of the Arab uprisings, President Mohamed Morsi is reaching out to Iran and other regional powers in an initiative to halt the escalating violence in Syria.

articles.headline: Apple Case Muddies the Future of Innovations
articles.snippet: For companies that emphasize distinctive design, the Samsung patent verdict was a validation of their efforts.
articles.abstract: For companies that emphasize distinctive design, the Samsung patent verdict was a validation of their efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple’s victory on Friday in a patent lawsuit against Samsung could, if upheld, give its rivals a kick in the pants to create more original products.

articles.headline: These Days, It’s Back to School, Then Shopping
articles.snippet: In an effort to follow trends, students and their families are delaying back-to-school purchases, which could hurt an economy heavily dependent on consumer spending to stay afloat.
articles.abstract: In an effort to follow trends, students and their families are delaying back-to-school purchases, which could hurt an economy heavily dependent on consumer spending to stay afloat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samantha Paradise is starting eighth grade in Manhattan next week, but she won’t be decked out in all new gear on the first day.

articles.headline: Storm Rewrites G.O.P.’s Script for Convention
articles.snippet: With Tropical Storm Isaac now forecast to roar past Tampa on Monday and Tuesday, officials scrambled to make contingency plans.
articles.abstract: With Tropical Storm Isaac now forecast to roar past Tampa on Monday and Tuesday, officials scrambled to make contingency plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The prospect of a major storm blowing through the Gulf of Mexico toward New Orleans upset the tight choreography of the Republican convention on Sunday, straining the party’s highly scripted plans for showcasing Mitt Romney and raising the possibility that news media attention could shift elsewhere.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: A Regulator’s Key Role in Failed Mutual Fund Reform
articles.snippet: Luis A. Aguilar, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, opposed a plan to reform money market funds, derailing a significant effort to tighten regulations on the financial industry.
articles.abstract: Luis A. Aguilar, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, opposed a plan to reform money market funds, derailing a significant effort to tighten regulations on the financial industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Luis A. Aguilar, one of five members of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is generally known as one of its strongest advocates for tougher oversight of the securities industry. In public statements this year, he has pushed his S.E.C. colleagues to be more aggressive, contending that the commission was not protecting investors assiduously enough.

articles.headline: A Party of Factions Gathers, Seeking Consensus
articles.snippet: Republican leaders said there was unity in the drive to unseat President Obama, but they expressed concerns about challenges to the establishment.
articles.abstract: Republican leaders said there was unity in the drive to unseat President Obama, but they expressed concerns about challenges to the establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney arrives here this week to accept his nomination from the increasingly disparate coalition of factions known as the Republican Party, confronting the challenge of unifying them behind him and — should he win — exerting his own authority over a party that is in many ways still forging a post-Bush identity.

articles.headline: Before Gunfire, Hints of ‘Bad News’
articles.snippet: James Eagan Holmes left no trail of hate behind him before the shootings in Aurora. But interviews with people who knew or had contact with him before the attack tell a story of a man struggling with a mental illness and losing his footing.
articles.abstract: James Eagan Holmes left no trail of hate behind him before the shootings in Aurora. But interviews with people who knew or had contact with him before the attack tell a story of a man struggling with a mental illness and losing his footing.
articles.lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — The text message, sent to another graduate student in early July, was cryptic and worrisome. Had she heard of “dysphoric mania,” James Eagan Holmes wanted to know?
articles.byline: By Erica Goode, Serge F. Kovaleski, Jack Healy and Dan Frosch

articles.headline: As Storm Disrupts Plans, G.O.P. Takes Up Tensions
articles.snippet: Monday was a day of frustration for Republicans as the delay in beginning their convention deprived them of their national stage and brought a fresh airing of intraparty tensions.
articles.abstract: Monday was a day of frustration for Republicans as the delay in beginning their convention deprived them of their national stage and brought a fresh airing of intraparty tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — It was supposed to be the start of their four-day effort to sell Mitt Romney to the nation, but Monday instead proved to be a day of frustration for Republicans as the delay in beginning their convention deprived them of their national stage and brought a fresh airing of intraparty tensions.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Michael D. Shear
